thread.title: Adorable orphaned dik-dik has to be bottled-fed by staff at Chester Zoo
thread.title_full: Adorable orphaned dik-dik has to be bottled-fed by staff at Chester Zoo

author: Adam Boult
title: Adorable orphaned dik-dik has to be bottled-fed by staff at Chester Zoo
text:
Adorable orphaned dik-dik has to be bottled-fed by staff at Chester Zoo Watch | Adorable orphaned dik-dik bottled-fed by staff at Chester Zoo 00:32 9 February 2017 â€¢ 5:41pm 
T his tiny antelope was left orphaned after its mother died shortly after giving birth at Chester Zoo. 
The 19-centimetre-tall animal, named Thanos, is now being cared for by zoo staff, who are bottle-feeding him five times a day. Chester zoo keepers are now caring for the antelope Credit: Chester Zoo/Cover Images 
T hanos is a Kirk's dik-dik, one of the world's smallest breeds of antelope. When fully grown he'll be just 40cm tall and at the moment he's so small his weight doesn't register on the zoo's scales. 
Kim Wood, assistant team manager at Chester Zoo, said: "The youngster is beginning to find his feet now and is really starting to hold his own. He is doing ever so well and is getting stronger by the day. Thanos strikes a pose for the camera Credit: Chester Zoo/Cover Images 
"We're hopeful that, in a few months' time, we'll be able to introduce him to some of the other members of our group of dik-diks. He may be tiny but he is certainly making a big impression on everyone at the zoo." 
K irk's dik-diks come from North East Africa, and take their name from 19th century Scottish naturalist Sir John Kirk. 
According to the African Wildlife Foundation, the biggest threat to dik-diks living in the wild is humans, who use snares to trap the animals, then turn their skins into suede for gloves, and their bones for jewelry. Staff bottle-feed him five times a day Credit: Chester Zoo/Cover Images 
D espite their diminutive stature they're not the world's smallest antelope - that title goes to the West African royal antelope, which grows to just 30cm tall. Follow Telegraph News
